data.title: Alessandro Farnese. Viceroy of the Lost Netherlands
data.meta_description: Becoming governors (stathouder) of the practically lost Netherlands, Alessandro Farnese managed to save 10 provinces for Spain out of 17 Alessandro Farnese 1546-92, 3rd Duke of Parma, Govenor-General of the Netherlands. Hispano-Dutch School, 1580s Today we continue the story of Alessandro Farnese,
data.text:
Alessandro Farnese 1546–1592, 3rd Duke of Parma, Govenor-General of the Netherlands. Hispano-Dutch School, 1580s

Today we will continue the story of Alessandro Farnese, the son of the illegitimate daughter of the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V, the half-brother of the Spanish King Philip II and the nephew of Juan of Austria. In the previous article, we left him in a military camp near Namur, where on October 1, 1578, before he reached the age of 32, only Juan of Austria, recently appointed stathouder of the Netherlands, died. His successor was Alessandro Farnese.

Alessandro Farnese

The first successes of Alessandro Farnese

It must be said that Farnese, unlike his predecessors, seems to have immediately decided to set realistic goals for himself and achieve only what was possible to achieve. He turned his main attention to the southern provinces, which were dominated by the Catholic population and whose leaders could compromise with the royal power. The irreconcilable Calvinistic north interested him only in the second place.

If the Duke of Alba, Requesens and Juan of Austria considered the Netherlands as an indivisible territory, then Farnese went to a separate agreement with the Walloons of the southern regions, splitting the front of resistance to royal power. He even removed almost all Spaniards from senior posts, preferring to rely on local cadres. True, there were many Italians in Farnese's personal environment. The Calvinists, who by this time had come to power in many cities of the southern provinces of the Netherlands, Farnese themselves "helped": "virtuous Protestants" began to oppress the Catholic majority quite cruelly.

As a result, the sympathies of many residents of the southern provinces suddenly swung towards the central government, and on January 6, 1579, Alessandro Farnese managed to conclude an agreement with their representatives, which was included in history like the Union of Arras. Catholicism was declared the dominant religion, the power of Philip II was recognized, while the Spaniards, in response, had to withdraw their troops from the Netherlands within 6 months. The Calvinists of the 7 northern provinces, in response, after 2 weeks concluded the Union of Utrecht, proclaiming their goal to be the struggle for independence and freedom of religion. William of Orange declared Philip II a tyrant and refused to obey him, who, in turn, called William a personal enemy.

Anthony More. Portrait of William of Orange

Philip II was dissatisfied with Farnese, considering his concessions to the Walloons to be excessive. On March 3, 1580, he again appointed Margaret of Parma as the stathouder of the Netherlands, but on November 13 of the following year he was forced to cancel this decision. In that year, the situation in the northern provinces of the Netherlands escalated to such an extent that the States General finally adopted an official decree on the deposition of Philip II. And the rebels had a new "headache": it was necessary to urgently find a person who would agree to accept the crown from them. Elizabeth of England renounced the throne of the Netherlands, rightly deciding that it was one thing to support the Calvinists there in their struggle against Spain, and quite another to be the queen of these unpredictable scumbags. And the Duke of Anjou Francois, the younger brother of the French king Henry III, did not like the rebels themselves.

It got to the point that he decided to usurp power and on January 17, 1583, the French troops stationed near Antwerp, Dunkirchen and Thurmond attacked these cities, but were repulsed by local residents. They tried to recognize the ruler of Richard Dudley, Earl of Leicester, the favorite of the English Queen Elizabeth. But in the end, the Republic of the Seven United Low Countries (Netherlands) had to be created, which lasted until 1795, when it was conquered by revolutionary France - and became the Batavian Republic. But let's not get ahead of ourselves.

Alessandro Farnese, having signed the Union of Arras, not only lost experienced fighters, but also could not count on reinforcements from Spain and Italy. Under his command were only about 15 thousand Flemish Catholics of the southern provinces. However, adding German mercenaries to them, at the beginning of 1579 he went on the offensive and soon laid siege to Mastricht. After a 4-month siege, the city was taken by storm, during which out of control soldiers killed many citizens. After that, the cities of Bois-le-Duc and Mechelen preferred to surrender, the inhabitants of which themselves expelled the Calvinist garrisons.

In the same 1579, even Count Philippe d'Egmont, who fought against the Spaniards in the battle of Gembloux, went over to the side of Farnese, whose father was executed in Brussels on the orders of the Duke of Alba. On March 14, 1590, 32-year-old Count Philip died in Normandy, where, on the orders of Farnese, he brought about two thousand soldiers to help the troops of the Catholic League. It happened during the "War of the Three Heinrichs" - in the battle of Ivry.

On February 27, 1580, Courtrai recognized the power of the king.

Farnese's forces were not enough, and therefore he could not afford constant active hostilities. However, in November 1581, he succeeded in taking the Walloon city of Tournai (the last city in the south remaining loyal to the States-General was now Ostend). The garrison of Tournai was allowed to leave, the inhabitants escaped robbery and violence by paying an indemnity of 200 florins. Calvinists who vowed to "live peacefully, without scandals" were allowed to stay in the city. Those who decided to leave were given the opportunity to sell their property.

By this time, Farnese, who was a good diplomat, already enjoyed the confidence of the Catholics of the southern provinces.

With the permission of the representatives of the southern lands, Farnese nevertheless returned the Spanish and Italian landsknechts to the Netherlands, which allowed him to go on the offensive at the end of 1582 and recapture Diest and Westerl by the middle of the next year. Then, in the first half of 1584, Farnese succeeded in subduing Ypres, Bruges, Ghent, Diet, Westerloo, Dunkirchen, Newport, Dix-maiden, Berg and Fürn. On March 10, 1585, Brussels surrendered, and its inhabitants were exempted from paying indemnities. On July 17 of the same year, Mechelen capitulated. Finally, on August 17, 1585, Antwerp fell, the siege of which lasted 13 months.

Siege of Antwerp in 1584–1585

By that time, William of Orange was already dead, who died as a result of an assassination attempt on July 10, 1584. Interestingly, it was he who became the first head of state to be shot with a pistol.

Assassination of William of Orange

Balthasar Gerards, the murderer of William of Orange, showed incredible courage during the three days of brutal torture before his execution. After some delay, Philip II granted his relatives the nobility and three estates in Burgundy, previously confiscated from William. Portrait by an unknown artist

Wilhelm's son Moritz turned out to be a talented commander and later won several victories over the Spaniards.

New opponents Alessandro Farnese

Already in 1586, Moritz captured the city of Axel, in 1588 at Bergen-op-Zom he managed to defeat Farnese himself, in March 1590 he captured Breda, in 1600 he put the Spaniards to flight at Newport. Moritz of Orange created a new one-line formation, in which the pikemen were in the center, and the musketeers were on the flanks, the number of pikemen and musketeers became the same. Reiters first appeared in Moritz's cavalry. Engineering units began to play a large role.

Maurits prins van Oranje in a portrait by Michiel van Mierevelt, between 1613–1620

In addition, in 1590, Moritz opened the world's first military academy, introduced a drill step and a number of commands, including “at attention”. Already at the turn of the XVIII-XIX centuries. Austrian Field Marshal Charles-Joseph Le Lin called military affairs "the science of Moritz". However, it must be said that the cousin of Moritz, Wilhelm Ludwig of Nassau-Dillenburg, also played a big role in the reform of the army of the Netherlands.

Willem Lodewijk van Nassau, portrait by Michiel Janson van Mierevelt, 1604

He is also known for the fact that in his army, according to the report of the Venetian ambassador, the salaries of the soldiers were never delayed, and they, in turn, paid their bills on time. As a result, cities in the Netherlands argued for the right to place garrisons in them, and the townspeople willingly let soldiers into their apartments, which was extremely surprising to contemporaries. In return, Wilhelm Ludwig demanded the strictest discipline from his subordinates and became one of the creators of the notorious drill. The soldiers were also required to participate in trench work, which was then considered an unworthy and humiliating occupation. Curiously, his letter to his brother:

“I discovered a way to make musketeers and soldiers armed with arquebuses not only shoot well, but also do it in battle formation, and not just skirmish or shoot under the cover of palisades: as soon as the first rank fires a volley, it, as taught, retreats . The second rank either advances or remains in place, makes a volley and also retreats. After that, the third and subsequent ranks do the same. Thus, before the last rank fires, the first has time to reload.

Does everything seem normal? However, at the end there is a postscript that “this can be a reason for ridicule”!

Subjugation of the southern provinces of the Netherlands

As for Alessandro Farnese, in 1586 he already controlled the territory on which modern Belgium is located. In the same year, his father died, and Alessandro received the title of Duke of Parma. But, as we remember, he did not return to Italy, his eldest son, Ranuccio, became his governor in Parma. The duke himself decided to complete the conquest of the Netherlands, which was a very difficult task. The territories of the three northern provinces - Holland, Zeeland and Utrecht, were washed by the sea from the north and west, in the east they were protected by the Zuiderzee and Issel, in the south - by the rivers Val and Meuse, as well as their mouth, common with the Scheldt. This is also, moreover, the same classic "country of dams" with a large number of earthen ramparts.

The Last Years of Alessandro Farnese's Life

Perhaps Farnese would still have succeeded, but King Philip II prevented him. In 1585, he started a war with England and ordered Farnese to prepare an army for crossing the English Channel. These plans were not carried out due to the unsuccessful actions of the admirals of the six squadrons of the Invincible Armada and the indecision of its commander, Alonso Perez de Guzman, Duke of Medina Sidonia (campaign to the coast of England in 1588). In 1589, the childless King Henry III of France was assassinated, and Philip II intervened in the war of the Catholic League. At first, he supported the Archbishop of Rouen, Charles de Bourbon, and then decided to nominate his daughter Isabella, born to his third wife, Elizabeth of Valois, the elder sister of Henry III, as a contender for the throne.

Alessandro's heir, Ranuccio, also took part in this war. Alessandro Farnese inflicted a number of defeats on the supporters of Henry of Navarre (the future King Henry IV), drove them away from Paris and Rouen, several times saving the army of the Catholic League from defeat and defeat. However, in the Netherlands at this time, the Spaniards were defeated by the army of Moritz of Orange. Alessandro Farnese no longer had time to correct the situation. In 1592 he was wounded at the Battle of Codbæk, from which he never recovered. The treatment on the waters of Spa did not help either: on December 3, 1592, he died in Arras. At the time of his death, he was only 47 years old. Only death saved Farnese from the shame of resignation, the decision on which was made by Philip II, who was dissatisfied with him. Time has shown that there was no worthy replacement for Alessandro Farnese as a commander and diplomat in Spain.

Belgium and the Netherlands

The war in the Netherlands continued until 1648 (with a 12-year truce 1609–1621). But the border between the southern and northern provinces, which had developed under Farnese, had practically not changed. However, the Protestants managed to take control of Vlissingen, which blocked the mouth of the Scheldt, which led to the gradual decline of the richest city in Europe, Antwerp. The palm passed from him to Calvinist Amsterdam, which became the reason for the centuries-old resentment of the inhabitants of the southern provinces against their northern neighbors. This insult is also mentioned in Charles de Coster's famous novel The Legend of Ulenspiegel. Spirits predict to the hero:

"At the hour when the north

Kiss the west

The destruction will end.

Look for the belt.

North - the Netherlands,

Belgium - West

Belt - friendship,

Belt - union.

Tie this belt

Netherlands with Belgium

Good friendship will

Glorious union.

Bonded by death

And with blood

So it would be

Whenever it wasn't for the Scheldt."

(Book Five, Chapter 9).

The territory, which Alessandro Farnese managed to take under the control, remained a Spanish possession until 1714, and then passed to Austria. Then it was conquered by the French Republic. The northern provinces of the Netherlands are often referred to simply as Holland. At the beginning of the 1602th century, for a short time, it became the most powerful maritime power, and the Netherlands East India Company, created in 1609, is considered the first transnational corporation in history. In 1652, the oldest stock exchange in the world, the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, appeared, which still exists today. The sailors of the northern provinces even reached Japan, where the word "rangaku" - "Dutch science" appeared. However, another predator was gaining strength in the west, and already in XNUMX the first Anglo-Dutch war began, of which there were three in the XNUMXth century and one more in the XNUMXth century. As you understand, it was the British who became the winners in this conflict, greatly squeezing out the Dutch competitors.

For the last time, Napoleon tried to unite the northern and southern provinces of the Netherlands, but the antagonism between them by this time was too great, the fragments did not grow together into a single whole. Moreover, even in modern Belgium there is still a distinct tension between the northern regions (Flanders) and the south (Wallonia). In the north, they speak Dutch and traditionally vote for right-wing politicians. In the south, mostly French is spoken (Walloon is spoken by less than 15% of the inhabitants of this part of the country), but German speakers live in the east of the province of Liège. Elections in Wallonia are usually won by the "left".

Language map of Belgium

Previously, the most economically developed region was Wallonia, now the palm has passed to Flanders, where separatist sentiments are very strong. Moreover, the gross regional product per capita in Flanders exceeds the Walloon one by about 1,4 times. Flanders also has a higher per capita income and even higher life expectancy. Many believe that Belgium would have split into two parts long ago if it were not for the French-speaking enclave in the Dutch-speaking north - the capital city of Brussels. In 1968, by the way, Belgium really almost collapsed during the so-called Louvain crisis, which was caused by a language conflict at the university of this city - they could not agree on which language to teach in.

According to a sociological survey conducted in March 2007 by the Tell me more institute, 70% of the Flemings are in favor of moving the capital from Brussels to another city, 94% of them want to see Antwerp as the new capital.

Ryzhov V.A.
